title: Téléroman
text:
A téléroman ("telenovel" or "annual drama series") is a genre of <a href="French-language">French-language</a> <a href="dramatic%20programming">drama</a> <a href="television%20series">television series</a> in <a href="Canada">Canada</a>, similar to a <a href="soap%20opera">soap opera</a> or a <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish language</a> <a href="telenovela">telenovela</a>. In <a href="France">France</a>, the "téléroman" genre is known as feuilleton télévisé (similar to a <a href="Serial%20%28radio%20and%20television%29">serial</a>). "Téléromans" are one of the most popular television series formats in Québécois <a href="Culture%20of%20Quebec">culture</a> and are also shown on French television.
In Canada, all of the major francophone television networks air "téléromans", including the public broadcaster <a href="Ici%20Radio-Canada%20T%C3%A9l%C3%A9">Radio-Canada</a>, which broadcasts them nationally, and the private networks <a href="TVA%20%28Canadian%20TV%20network%29">TVA</a> and <a href="Noovo">Noovo</a>. <a href="TFO">TFO</a> in <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a> has also produced one téléroman.
In France, the <a href="TF1">TF1</a> network and the subscription channel <a href="Canal%2B">Canal+</a> air "feuilletons télévisés". Some famous téléromans produced in France include "Riviera", "Sous le soleil", "Plus belle la vie" and "Cinq sœurs".
One of the first téléromans on Canadian television was "<a href="La%20famille%20Plouffe">La famille Plouffe</a>". This "téléroman" proved highly successful, and has helped the genre become a staple on Canadian French television. English Canadian networks have also adapted a number of Québec téléromans for English viewers, including "La famille Plouffe", "<a href="Lance%20et%20Compte">Lance et Compte</a>" and "<a href="Les%20Hauts%20et%20les%20bas%20de%20Sophie%20Paquin">Les Hauts et les bas de Sophie Paquin</a>", with varying degrees of success.
